title: Official Blind Review #2
review_assessment:_checking_correctness_: I assessed the sensibility of the derivations and theory.
review:
The paper investigates to what degree Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) learn to encode positional information.
Rather interesting finding is the not only they do encode this information, but that it is to a large degree function of the padding commonly used in the CNN architectures.

The problem the paper is looking at is well motivated, the experiments are nicely designed and it includes comprehensive ablation study.
Previous and related work seems to be well referenced.
The main idea of introducing the PosENet to predict the gradient map is neat, and allows for interesting experiments (e.g. what layers most strongly encode the positional information).

I really enjoyed the paper, the overall quality is high and does not seem to be rushed (no obvious typos or mistakes in the figures/tables).
I believe this should be an accept.

Q:
I can understand why you removed the pooling layers, but did you try to run some of your experiments with these as well? How were the numbers effected?
